dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, I was reading this really, uh, thought-provoking article by Aliya Bizhanova, you know, the OECD consultant?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, I was reading this really, uh, thought-provoking article by Aliya Bizhanova, you know, the O E C D consultant?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aliya Bizhanova, Almaty Management University researcher, OECD consultant

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, about the PISA results for Kazakhstan, right? I saw some headlines, pretty grim.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, about the P I S A results for Kazakhstan, right? I saw some headlines, pretty grim.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: S Kazakhstan participates in PISA since 2009.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Grim is an understatement, honestly. She points out that our 15-year-olds, their reading scores, like, barely moved since 2009, but compared to the OECD average, it's over a *two-school-year* difference. We're 7th last out of 77 countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Grim is an understatement, honestly. She points out that our fifteen-year-olds, their reading scores, like, barely moved since two thousand nine, but compared to the O E C D average, it's over a two-school-year difference. We're seventh last out of seventy seven countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When it comes to reading literacy, Kazakhstan is the 9th last out of 77 countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wow. Seventh last? That's, uh, that's really saying something about our reading literacy, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Seventh last? That's, uh, that's really saying something about our reading literacy, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And she says it's not just the education system, although that plays a part. She talks about this direct link between fewer books at home and lower literacy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And she says it's not just the education system, although that plays a part. She talks about this direct link between fewer books at home and lower literacy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: OECD results show, that there is direct link between decreasing number of books at home and students literacy level.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, that culture of reading, it's not born in school, is it? It's when a parent reads to a one-year-old, or even younger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, that culture of reading, it's not born in school, is it? It's when a parent reads to a one-year-old, or even younger.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The culture of reading is not being born in school, it becomes a habit when a mother or father read to their child when he or she is one-year-old or younger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! She even mentioned Austria, where they give books to 9-month-old babies during clinic visits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! She even mentioned Austria, where they give books to nine-month-old babies during clinic visits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, to encourage family reading time, 9-month old baby and his/her parents in Great Britain are provided books during outpatients clinic visit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's such a smart initiative! Like, setting the foundation so early.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's such a smart initiative! Like, setting the foundation so early.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then, get this, she moves on to libraries. Oh, our libraries...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, get this, she moves on to libraries. Oh, our libraries...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Don't even get me started. Dark rooms, dusty books, like a time capsule from the Soviet era, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Don't even get me started. Dark rooms, dusty books, like a time capsule from the Soviet era, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is Soviet environment, books are outdated, nothing has changed since 1980-ies. ... How about our libraries? There are dark rooms with dusty stacks of books.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! She says she works from her district library sometimes, and it's, uh, two or three people max visiting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! She says she works from her district library sometimes, and it's, uh, two or three people max visiting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on my experience, do you know how many people visit a library to read or take/return books? You will be shocked, but it is usually one or two people maximum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I believe it. When you travel, you see libraries in other countries, they're like vibrant community centers, events for kids and adults...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I believe it. When you travel, you see libraries in other countries, they're like vibrant community centers, events for kids and adults...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Libraries in developed countries are considered centers of districts called Community Centers, where interesting events take place for adults and kids

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, with e-libraries, bright spaces, not just, you know, stacks of outdated books.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, with e-libraries, bright spaces, not just, you know, stacks of outdated books.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: there are great e-library resources, public events, play time, there is light and open space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, her point is, instead of spending huge amounts on, like, Expo or new curbs, maybe we should, um, invest in transforming these libraries?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, her point is, instead of spending huge amounts on, like, Expo or new curbs, maybe we should, um, invest in transforming these libraries?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It then makes more sense to invest in local libraries and in their transformation, rather than to spend huge amounts of money on Expo exhibition or new curbs that are regularly replaced in Almaty city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Make them places people *want* to go. Attract the general public, our kids included.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Make them places people want to go. Attract the general public, our kids included.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So that the libraries attract general public, including us and our kids...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that just makes so much sense, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that just makes so much sense, doesn't it?
